official-title.#text:
To update avian protection laws in order to support an all-of-the-above domestic energy strategy,
			 and for other purposes.

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Clarification of Legal Enforcement Against Non-criminal Energy Producers Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Clarification of Legal Enforcement Against Non-criminal Energy Producers Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
(MBTA) was enacted in 1918 to protect the migratory bird population
			 from overhunting and poaching and has not been updated to reflect the
			 societal changes that have occurred in our Nation over the last 95 years.

text.#text:
Anyone involved in an otherwise legal activity may be subject to criminal liability for the
			 unintentional death of any one of over 1,000 species of birds protected
			 under the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
(BGEPA), was first enacted in 1940 to protect the dwindling
			 population of bald eagles and amended in 1962 to cover golden eagles in
			 order to provide additional protective measures for bald eagles and for
			 other purposes.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Bald and Golden Eagle
			 Protection Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Bald and Golden Eagle Protection Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
includes a program for the Federal Government to issue permits in order to protect
			 companies from legal liability if eagles are unintentionally injured or
			 killed, but the Federal Government has failed to issue permits issued
			 under the program.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Bald and Golden Eagle Protection Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
’s permit program was established to assure the protection of interests
			 fundamental to the basic operation of our society like agriculture and
			 energy infrastructure development and maintenance.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Bald and Golden Eagle Protection Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
was successful in helping the overall eagle population recover, leading to bald eagles
			 being removed from the list of threatened and endangered species in 2007.

text.#text:
There are differing legal and judicial interpretations regarding the scope of criminality in those
			 statutes.

It appears criminal prosecution under those statutes has been subjective, selective, and not
			 applied uniformly and fairly across all sectors of society.

Those statutes need to be updated to reflect significant changes in our Nation over the last half
			 century, including the urbanization of rural areas and how domestic energy
			 is produced, transmitted, and distributed.
Protecting the avian population and its habitat is important.
Federal enforcement actions should be appropriate, uniform, nondiscriminatory, and just.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, is amended by adding at the end the
			 following:
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Bald and
			 Golden Eagle Protection Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Bald and Golden Eagle Protection Act

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 1 of the Act of June 8, 1940
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Bald and Golden Eagle Protection Act/s:1

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall issue or deny an
			 eagle take permit for no less than 30 years under section 22.26 of title
			 50, Code of Federal Regulations, that authorizes taking of any bald eagle
			 or golden eagle that is incidental to, but not the purpose of, an
			 otherwise lawful activity. Failure to issue or deny such a permit within a
			 reasonable time (which shall not exceed one year) is deemed issuance of
			 such permit, and the applicant shall not be subject to liability for any
			 incidental take of a bald eagle or golden eagle that is in conformity with
			 the information submitted to the Secretary as part of the application for
			 the permit.

text.#text: Upon submission of a substantially completed application, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 6(a) of the Migratory Bird Treaty Act

quote.#tail: the first and second place it appears and inserting

does not include any taking, killing, or other harm to any migratory bird that is accidental or
			 incidental to the presence or operation of an otherwise lawful activity.

quote.#text: For the purposes of this subsection,

text.#text: by adding at the end the following:
